definition:
[*Hosoya’s triangle*]{} or the [*Fibonacci triangle*]{} is a triangular
arrangement of numbers (like Pascal’s triangle) based on the Fibonacci
numbers. Each number is the sum of the two numbers above in either the
left diagonal or the right diagonal. The first few rows are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccccccc}
& & & & & & & & & 1 & & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & & 1 & & 1 & & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & & 2 & & 1 & & 2 & & & & & &\\
& & & & & & 3 & & 2 & & 2 & & 3 & & & & &\\
& & & & & 5 & & 3 & & 4 & & 3 & & 5 & & & &\\
& & & & 8 & & 5 & & 6 & & 6 & & 5 & & 8 & & &\\
& & & 13 & & 8 & & 10 & & 9 & & 10 & & 8 & & 13 & &\\
& & 21 & & 13 & & 16 & & 15 & & 15 & & 16 & & 13 & & 21 &\\
& & & & &\vdots & & & & \vdots & & & & \vdots& & & & \\
\end{array}\end{aligned}$$

(See sequence A058071 in Sloaen’s OEIS). The recurrence relation is
$H(0, 0) = H(1, 0) = H(1, 1) = H(2, 1) = 1$ and
$H(n, j) = H(n - 1, j) + H(n - 2, j)$ or
$H(n, j) = H(n - 1, j - 1) + H(n - 2, j - 2)$.

Thus, the two outermost diagonals are the Fibonacci numbers, while the
numbers on the middle vertical line are the squares of the Fibonacci
numbers. All the other numbers in the triangle are the product of two
distinct Fibonacci numbers greater than 1. The row sums are the
convolved Fibonacci numbers (A001629 in Sloane’s OEIS).
